member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AIChannel
member.summary: Encapsulates one or more analog input virtual channels and the properties for an analog input virtual channel.
member.remarks: Use the property to create or access an analog input virtual channel. An might contain more than one virtual channel because the is defined by providing a valid NI-DAQmx channel string to the indexer or to an create virtual channel method. If you set a property on an object that represents multiple virtual channels, that property is set for all of the virtual channels that the object represents.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AIChannel.PerformBridgeOffsetNullingCalibration
member.summary: Performs a bridge offset nulling calibration on the virtual channels in the task. An error will occur if not all virtual channels in the task support this operation.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: This method adjusts the , , and properties to eliminate voltage offset in the virtual channel. If the acquisition device does not have a built-in potentiometer, only the initial bridge voltage attribute is adjusted.

The task must not be reserved, committed, or started. All virtual channel configurations must be complete prior to calling this method. The physical channel must remain in the state at which you expect to read 0 V from the bridge while the method executes.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AIChannel.CalibrationExpirationDate
member.summary: Gets or sets the date and time that the channel calibration expires.
member.value: The date and time that the channel calibration expires.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AIChannel.CalibrationDate
member.summary: Gets or sets the last date and time that the channel underwent a channel calibration.
member.value: The last date and time that the channel underwent a channel calibration.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AIChannel.PerformBridgeOffsetNullingCalibration(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Performs a bridge offset nulling calibration on the virtual channels in the task.
member.param: Specifies whether or not to skip channels that do not support shunt calibration. If is , shunt calibration will be performed only on supported virtual channels in the task. If , shunt calibration will be performed on all virtual channels in the task, which may result in an error if not all channels support shunt calibration.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: This method adjusts the , , and properties to eliminate voltage offset in the virtual channel. If the acquisition device does not have a built-in potentiometer, only the initial bridge voltage attribute is adjusted.

The task must not be reserved, committed, or started. All virtual channel configurations must be complete prior to calling this method. The physical channel must remain in the state at which you expect to read 0 V from the bridge while the method executes.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AIChannel.PerformThermocoupleLeadOffsetNullingCalibration(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Performs thermocouple lead offset nulling calibration on the channels in the task to compensate for offsets introduced by open thermocouple detection. Use this method to specify whether or not to skip channels that do not support calibration.
member.param: Specifies whether or not to skip channels that do not support calibration. If is , calibration will be performed only on supported virtual channels in the task. If , calibration will be performed on all virtual channels in the task, which may result in an error if not all channels support calibration.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks: Keep the measured temperature as constant as possible while performing this adjustment.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AIChannel.PerformThermocoupleLeadOffsetNullingCalibration
member.summary: Performs thermocouple lead offset nulling calibration on the channels in the task to compensate for offsets introduced by open thermocouple detection. An error will occur if not all virtual channels in the task support this operation.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks: Keep the measured temperature as constant as possible while performing this adjustment.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AIChannel.BridgeInitialVoltage
member.summary: Specifies in volts the output voltage of the bridge while not under load. NI-DAQmx subtracts this value from any measurements before applying scaling equations. If you set , NI-DAQmx coerces this property to times . This property is set by DAQmx Perform Bridge Offset Nulling Calibration. If you set this property, NI-DAQmx coerces to the value of this property divided by . If you set both this property and , and their values conflict, NI-DAQmx returns an error. To avoid this error, reset one property to its default value before setting the other.

member.summary: Specifies whether to apply the open thermocouple detection bias voltage to the channel. When open thermocouple detection is enabled, use to determine if any channels were open.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AOChannel
member.summary: Encapsulates one or more analog output channels and the properties for an analog output channel.
member.remarks: Use the property to create or access an analog output channel. An might contain more than one virtual channel because the is defined by providing a valid NI-DAQmx channel string to the indexer or to an create channel method. If you set a property on a object that represents multiple channels, that property is set for all of the channels that the object represents.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AOChannel.ReglitchEnable
member.summary: Specifies whether to enable reglitching. The output of a DAC normally glitches whenever the DAC is updated with a new value. The amount of glitching differs from code to code and is generally largest at major code transitions. Reglitching generates uniform glitch energy at each code transition and provides for more uniform glitches. Uniform glitch energy makes it easier to filter out the noise introduced from glitching during spectrum analysis.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AOChannel.DeviceScalingCoefficients
member.summary: Indicates the coefficients of a linear equation that NI-DAQmx uses to scale values from a voltage to the native format of the device. Each element of the array corresponds to a term of the equation. The first element of the array corresponds to the y-intercept, and the second element corresponds to the slope. Scaling coefficients do not account for any custom scales that may be applied to the channel.

remarks.para: This property returns a copy of the actual array. Avoid calling this property within a for loop because it creates a copy for each iteration of the loop. Avoid using an indexer to set a member of the array because the indexer returns a copy of the object and has no effect on the actual object.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DIChannel.DigitalFilterEnableBusMode
member.summary: Specifies whether to enable bus mode for digital filtering. If you set this property to , NI-DAQmx treats all lines that use common filtering settings as a bus. If any line in the bus has jitter, all lines in the bus hold state until the entire bus stabilizes, or until 2 times the minimum pulse width elapses. If you set this property to , NI-DAQmx filters all lines individually. Jitter in one line does not affect other lines.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DOChannel.Tristate
member.summary: Specifies whether to stop driving the channel and set it to a high-impedance state. You must commit the task for this setting to take effect.
member.value: Specifies whether to stop driving the channel and set it to a high-impedance state. You must commit the task for this setting to take effect.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: Setting this property before you commit the task determines whether NI-DAQmx drives data on the channel or tristates the channel after the task transitions to the committed state.
Use this property when you want to read and write to channels in a task. Set this property to before you read from the channel and set this property to before you write to the channel.
When you read from an output channel that is not tristated, the value corresponds to the current value you are driving on the channel.

When you write to a channel that is tristated, no change occurs until you set this property to . After you set this property to , the value NI-DAQmx drives on the channel corresponds to the last value written to the channel.

Ensure the channel is tristated before any external devices that you connect to the channel drive data onto the channel. Failure to do so could result in double-driving the channel and damaging the device.
This property is supported only for line-configurable, bidirectional ports.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.CIChannel.FrequencyMeasurementTime
member.summary: Specifies in seconds the length of time to measure the frequency of the signal if is . member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.CIChannel.EncoderDecodingType
member.summary: Specifies how to count and interpret the pulses the encoder generates on signal A and signal B. , , and are valid for quadrature encoders only. is valid for two-pulse encoders only.
member.value: Specifies how to count and interpret the pulses the encoder generates on signal A and signal B. , , and are valid for quadrature encoders only. is valid for two-pulse encoders only.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: X2 and X4 decoding are more sensitive to smaller changes in position than X1 encoding, with X4 being the most sensitive. However, more sensitive decoding is more likely to produce erroneous measurements if vibration exists in the encoder or other noise exists in the signals.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.CIChannel.EncoderZIndexPhase
member.summary: Specifies the states at which signal A and signal B must be while signal Z is high for NI-DAQmx to reset the measurement. If signal Z is never high while signal A and signal B are high, for example, you must choose a phase other than .
member.value: Specifies the states at which signal A and signal B must be while signal Z is high for NI-DAQmx to reset the measurement. If signal Z is never high while signal A and signal B are high, for example, you must choose a phase other than .
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: When signal Z transitions to high and how long it stays high varies from encoder to encoder. Refer to the documentation for the encoder to determine the timing of signal Z with respect to signal A and signal B.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.CIChannel.CounterTimebaseSource
member.summary: Specifies the terminal of the timebase to use for the counter.
member.value: Specifies the terminal of the timebase to use for the counter.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: Typically, NI-DAQmx uses one of the internal counter timebases when performing counter measurements. Use this property to specify an external timebase and produce custom measurement ranges that are not possible with the internal timebases.

You also can use this property to chain counters together. By using the output of a counter as the timebase of another counter, you can effectively widen a counter. For example, you can chain two 24 bit counters together to produce one 48 bit counter.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.CIChannel.CounterTimebaseRate
member.summary: Specifies in Hertz the frequency of the counter timebase. Specifying the rate of a counter timebase allows you to take measurements in terms of time or frequency rather than in ticks of the timebase. If you use an external timebase and do not specify the rate, you can take measurements only in terms of ticks of the timebase.
member.value: Specifies in Hertz the frequency of the counter timebase. Specifying the rate of a counter timebase allows you to take measurements in terms of time or frequency rather than in ticks of the timebase. If you use an external timebase and do not specify the rate, you can take measurements only in terms of ticks of the timebase.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.value: Specifies whether a timebase cycle is from rising edge to rising edge or from falling edge to falling edge.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.CIChannel.NumberPossiblyInvalidSamples
member.summary: Indicates the number of samples that the device might have overwritten before it could transfer them to the buffer.
member.value: Indicates the number of samples that the device might have overwritten before it could transfer them to the buffer.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: On certain devices during finite buffered time measurements, it is not possible to detect if the counter overwrites a value it read before the device could transfer the sample to the buffer. This uncertainty is present only when is and occurs as the acquisition nears completion.

Once the acquisition completes, it is impossible to tell if the status value on the counter indicates an overwrite as a result of a true overwrite, or because the counter detected another edge of the input signal after the acquisition completed but before the counter could disarm. As a result of this behavior, higher frequency input signals are more likely to increase the number of possibly invalid samples.

To decrease the number of possibly invalid samples, read more often from the buffer. Reading from the buffer forces a check on the hardware status and ensures all data is valid up to the present point in the buffer. By default, NI-DAQmx checks the validity of data every fourth of the buffer. If you do not perform a read until after the device acquires all data, the value of this property is one-fourth of the buffer size or zero.
The value this property indicates is valid only while the task is in the running state. The value of this property while the task is in any other state is zero.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.CIChannel.MaximumMeasurementPeriod
member.summary: Specifies the maximum period (in seconds) in which the device will recognize signals. For frequency measurements, a signal with a higher period than the one set in this property will return 0 Hz. For duty cycle, the device will return 0 or 1 depending on the state of the line during the max defined period of time. Period measurements will return NaN. Pulse width measurement will return zero.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.COChannel
member.summary: Encapsulates one or more counter/timer output channels and the properties for a counter/timer output channel.
member.remarks: Use the property to create or access a counter/timer output channel. A might contain more than one virtual channel because the is defined by providing a valid NI-DAQmx channel string to the indexer or to a create channel method. If you set a property on a object that represents multiple channels, that property is set for all of the channels that the object represents.

remarks.para: When this value is greater than 0, NI-DAQmx generates progressively longer pulses until the count register rolls over. At that point, the generated pulses return to the original pulse width and grow progressively longer until the count register rolls over again.

Use this property to provide a clock to an analog input channel for equivalent time sampling (ETS). ETS is a data acquisition technique in which data on a periodic waveform with a frequency higher than the Nyquist frequency of the system is obtained by sampling the waveform at instants in time skewed in relation to the beginning of each period of the waveform.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.COChannel.ConstrainedGenerationMode
member.summary: Specifies constraints to apply when the counter generates pulses. Constraining the counter reduces the device resources required for counter operation. Constraining the counter can also allow additional analog or counter tasks on the device to run concurrently. For continuous counter tasks, NI-DAQmx consumes no device resources when the counter is constrained. For finite counter tasks, resource use increases with the frequency regardless of the constraint mode. However, fixed frequency constraints significantly reduce resource usage, and fixed duty cycle constraint marginally reduces it.
member.value: Specifies constraints to apply when the counter generates pulses. Constraining the counter reduces the device resources required for counter operation. However, fixed frequency constraints significantly reduce resource usage, and fixed duty cycle constraint marginally reduces it.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Timing.ConfigureSampleClock(System.String,System.Double,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.SampleClockActiveEdge,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.SampleQuantityMode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the source of the sample clock, the rate of the sample clock, and the number of samples to acquire or generate.
member.param: The source terminal of the clock. To use the internal clock of the device, set this value to .
The sampling rate in samples per second. If you use an external source for the sample clock, set this input to the maximum expected rate of that clock.
The edges of sample clock pulses on which to acquire or generate samples.

The duration of the task. A task is either finite and stops once the specified number of samples have been acquired or generated, or it is continuous and continues to acquire or generate samples until the task is explicitly stopped.
The number of samples to acquire or generate if is . If sample mode is , NI-DAQmx uses this value to determine the buffer size.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks:
The NI-DAQmx driver does not determine if the requested settings are possible until the task is verified. this method does not throw an exception for parameter values that are not compatible with your hardware or other settings in your task. To determine if all of the settings for a are valid, you must verify the task by starting the task, either with or by reading from or writing to the task, or by calling with .
You cannot apply this method to a subset of devices in the task, and you must apply this method to the task as a whole. You must call this method on the instance of returned from the property on the class. Accessing this method on instances of returned from the property throws an exception.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Timing.ConfigurePipelinedSampleClock(System.String,System.Double,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.SampleClockActiveEdge,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.SampleQuantityMode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the source of the sample clock, the rate of the sample clock, the number of samples to acquire or generate, and configures the sample clock for pipelining.
member.param: The source terminal of the clock. To use the internal clock of the device, set this value to .
The sampling rate in samples per second. If you use an external source for the sample clock, set this input to the maximum expected rate of that clock.
The edges of sample clock pulses on which to acquire or generate samples.

The duration of the task. A task is either finite and stops once the specified number of samples have been acquired or generated, or it is continuous and continues to acquire or generate samples until the task is explicitly stopped.
The number of samples to acquire or generate if is . If sample mode is , NI-DAQmx uses this value to determine the buffer size.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks:
The device acquires or generates samples on each sample clock edge, but does not respond to certain triggers until a few sample clock edges later. Pipelining allows higher data transfer rates at the cost of increased trigger response latency. Refer to the device documentation for information about which triggers pipelining affects. This timing type allows handshaking using the Pause trigger, the Ready for Transfer event, or the Data Active event. Refer to the device documentation for more information.
This timing type is supported only by the NI 6536 and NI 6537.
The NI-DAQmx driver does not determine if the requested settings are possible until the task is verified. This method does not throw an exception for parameter values that are not compatible with your hardware or other settings in your task. member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Timing.SampleTimingType
member.summary: Specifies the type of sample timing to use for the task.
member.value: Specifies the type of sample timing to use for the task.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: Select when a hardware signal (usually a clock) must acquire or produce samples. To perform buffered edge counting, for example, select and use to specify the source of the Sample clock.
Select to use bidirectional hardware signals to time the exchange of digital data between two devices.
Select to run at a slower rate but with the capability for per sample evaluation of triggers and events to pause the operation.
Select on supported devices to run at the maximum sample rate with a few Sample clock cycles delay before the device can respond to triggers and events.
Select to acquire data only when reading from the task executes or to generate data only when writing to the task executes.
Select to perform a buffered period or frequency counter measurement or to generate a finite pulse train.
Select to capture data only when certain digital lines change states and without continuously transferring unnecessary data during periods of inactivity.

member.value: Indicates the maximum Sample Clock rate supported by the task, based on other timing settings. For output tasks, the maximum Sample Clock rate is the maximum rate of the DAC. For input tasks, NI-DAQmx calculates the maximum sampling rate differently for multiplexed devices than simultaneous sampling devices.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: For multiplexed devices, NI-DAQmx calculates the maximum sample clock rate based on the maximum AI Convert Clock rate unless you set . If you set that property, NI-DAQmx calculates the maximum sample clock rate based on that setting. Use to query the maximum AI Convert Clock rate. NI-DAQmx also uses the minimum sample clock delay to calculate the maximum sample clock rate unless you set .
For simultaneous sampling devices, the maximum Sample Clock rate is the maximum rate of the ADC.

member.summary: Specifies in Hertz the rate at which to clock the analog-to-digital converter. This clock is specific to the analog input section of multiplexed devices.
member.value: Specifies in Hertz the rate at which to clock the analog-to-digital converter. This clock is specific to the analog input section of multiplexed devices.

remarks.para: By default, NI-DAQmx selects the maximum convert rate supported by the device, plus up to 10 microseconds per channel settling time. Other task settings, such as high channel counts or setting , can result in a faster default convert rate.
CompactDAQ applies up to 10 microseconds of settling time for all C Series devices even if the maximum convert rates of the devices differ.

If you connect signal conditioning accessories with track and hold capabilities, such as an SCXI module, to the device, NI-DAQmx uses the fastest convert rate possible that meets the settling requirements for the slowest module sampled. Refer to the device documentation for the signal conditioning accessory for more information.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Timing.AIConvertMaximumRate
member.summary: Indicates the maximum convert rate supported by the task, given the current devices and channel count.
member.value: Indicates the maximum convert rate supported by the task, given the current devices and channel count.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: This rate is generally faster than the default AI Convert Clock rate selected by NI-DAQmx, because NI-DAQmx adds in an additional 10 microseconds per channel settling time to compensate for most potential system settling constraints.

For single channel tasks, the maximum AI Convert Clock rate is the maximum rate of the ADC. For multiple channel tasks, the maximum AI Convert Clock rate is the maximum convert rate of the analog hardware, including the ADC, filters, multiplexers, and amplifiers. Signal conditioning accessories can further constrain the maximum AI Convert Clock based on timing and settling requirements.

member.summary: Indicates in seconds the amount of time required for the ADCs or DACs on the device to reset. member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Task
member.summary: Represents a collection of virtual channels and their per-channel properties and timing, triggering, and other properties that apply to the DAQmx Task.
member.remarks:
is the principal class that represents the channels, timing, triggering, exported signals, and other information about an NI-DAQmx task. For most tasks, in addition to the object, you must create an instance of a reader or writer class to read samples from or write samples to the of the task. To create a reader or writer for a particular , pass the property of that to the reader or writer constructor.
Some DAQ devices are not currently supported by the NI-DAQmx driver. Refer to NI-DAQ Readme for a complete listing of supported hardware.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Task.Start
member.summary: Transitions the task to the running state, which begins the measurement or generation.
member.remarks: If you do not use this method, a measurement task starts automatically when you call a read method. How you set the write method parameter determines if calling the write method automatically starts a generation task. If you do not use and when you use a read or write method multiple times, the task starts and stops repeatedly, which reduces the performance of the application. Refer to When Should You Use the Start Function for more information.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Task.Stop
member.summary: Transitions the task from the running to the committed state, which ends the measurement or generation.

remarks.para: If you do not use this method, the read method ends a measurement task automatically before returning. How you set the parameter of the write method determines if calling the write method automatically ends a generation task before returning. If you do not use and when you use a read or write method multiple times, the task starts and stops repeatedly, which reduces the performance of the application.

If an asynchronous read or write on the task is in progress, does not return until the data from the pending read or write has been transferred to or from the task buffer. does not wait for read or write asynchronous callback methods to finish, however.
You may pass to the method stop the task immediately, without waiting for any currently running operation to complete.

member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Task.Control(NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TaskAction)
member.summary: Alters the state of the task according to the mode you specify.
member.param: The action to use to alter the state of the task.

remarks.para: To start a task more quickly, set to to program the hardware with all parameters of the task prior to starting it.

If the task is in the running state and an asynchronous read or write on the task is in progress, calling to move the task out of the running state does not return until the data from the pending read or write has been transferred to or from the task buffer. However, if is , then does not wait for the asynchronous read or write callback methods to finish. The pending asynchronous call stops immediately and raises a .

member.summary: Adds a preconfigured, global channel to the task.
member.param: The name of the global channel to add to the task.
member.returns: The global .

remarks.para: A task can contain global or local channels. Global channels are accessible to all tasks on the system. Local channels are accessible only to the task you use to create them.

Use local channels in a typical application. Use the create channel methods on , , , , , or to create local channels and add them to the task. Use Measurement & Automation Explorer (MAX) to create, configure, and store global channels.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Task.ConfigureLogging(System.String,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TdmsLoggingOperation,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.LoggingMode)
member.summary: Configures logging to a .tdms file when the acquisition starts.
member.param: The path to the .tdms file to which you want to log data. If you use this method to create a new file, the file extension of the filename you specify in must be .tdms. Otherwise, this method automatically appends .tdms to the filename you specify. If you use this method to open or update an existing file, you do not have to ensure that the file extension is .tdms.
A value that specifies how to open the .tdms file.
A value that specifies how to log data.
member.remarks: When you enable TDMS logging, NI-DAQmx streams the data acquired to the specified file once the acquisition starts. The data written on the file is in TDMS file format, and the driver also creates a TDMS index file. The name of the TDMS channel group that the driver creates is the same as the task name. Refer to TDMS Streaming for more information.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Task.ConfigureLogging(System.String,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TdmsLoggingOperation,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.LoggingMode,System.String)
member.summary: Configures logging to a .tdms file when the acquisition starts with the specified TDMS channel group name.
member.param: The path to the .tdms file to which you want to log data. If you use this method to create a new file, the file extension of the filename you specify in must be .tdms. Otherwise, this method automatically appends .tdms to the filename you specify. If you use this method to open or update an existing file, you do not have to ensure that the file extension is .tdms.
A value which specifies how to open the .tdms file.
A value which specifies how to log data.
The name of the channel group to create within the .tdms file for data from this task. When set to , , or a string with only white space, the driver sets the TDMS channel group name to the task name.
member.remarks: When you enable TDMS logging, NI-DAQmx streams the data acquired to the specified file once the acquisition starts. The data written on the file is in TDMS file format, and the driver also creates a TDMS index file. Refer to TDMS Streaming for more information.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Device.ReserveNetworkDevice(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Reserves the Network DAQ device for the current host. Reservation is required to run NI-DAQmx tasks, and the device must be added in MAX before it can be reserved. Use this method to specify whether to override an existing reservation.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.note: This functionality is performed implicitly for the NI 9163, so this method is not supported on the NI 9163 carrier.
member.param: Specifies whether an existing reservation on the device should be overridden by this reservation.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Device.ReserveNetworkDevice
member.summary: Reserves the Network DAQ device for the current host. Reservation is required to run NI-DAQmx tasks, and the device must be added in MAX before it can be reserved. This method does not override any existing reservations on the device.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.note: This functionality is performed implicitly for the NI 9163, so this method is not supported on the NI 9163 carrier.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Device.SelfCalibrationTemperature
member.summary: Indicates in degrees Celsius the temperature of the device at the time of the last self-calibration. Compare this temperature to the current onboard temperature to determine if you should perform another calibration.
member.value: Indicates in degrees Celsius the temperature of the device at the time of the last self-calibration. Compare this temperature to the current onboard temperature to determine if you should perform another calibration.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: The temperature returned by this property is the calibration temperature as measured by an onboard temperature sensor and may differ from the temperature displayed on a printed calibration certificate. Calibration certificates usually display the ambient temperature rather than the onboard temperature.
Using Traditional NI-DAQ (Legacy) to perform calibration does not update this property. This property is updated only when you use NI-DAQmx to perform calibration.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Scale
member.summary: Encapsulates a custom scale that translates between prescaled quantities in device units and quantities scaled to the units of interest.

remarks.para: is the base class for , , , and . All instances of are of one of the derived class types. Refer to the derived class documentation for more information.

When you create a scale, you must provide the scale with a name because the scale is associated with channels through its name. You can create and configure a scale in Measurement Automation Explorer (MAX) or with the constructor of a class that derives from .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.LinearScale
member.summary: Encapsulates a linear custom scale that scales values using the equation y = mx + b.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.LinearScale.#ctor(System.String,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class that scales values using the equation y = mx + b, where x is the prescaled value, and y is the scaled value.
member.param: The name of the custom scale for later use, such as when you create a virtual channel.
The slope, m, in the equation.
The y-intercept, b, in the equation.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks: The equation is identical for input and output. If the equation is in the form x = my + b, you must first solve for y in terms of x.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem
member.summary: Contains methods that access tasks, scales, and global channels stored in Measurement Automation Explorer (MAX), performs immediate operations on DAQ hardware, and creates classes from which you can get information about the hardware.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.DisconnectTerminals(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Removes signal routes you created by using .
member.param: The originating terminal of the route.
The receiving terminal of the route.
member.remarks: This method cannot remove task-based routes, such as those you create through timing and triggering configuration. When this method is called, it immediately unreserves the route. This type of routing is called immediate routing.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.TristateOutputTerminal(System.String)
member.summary: Sets a terminal to high-impedance state.
member.param: The terminal on the I/O connector to set to high-impedance state.

remarks.para: If you connect an external signal to a terminal on the I/O connector, the terminal must be in high-impedance state. Otherwise, the device could double-drive the terminal and damage the hardware. If you call this method on a terminal in an active route, the method fails and reports no error back to the user.
sets all terminals on the I/O connector to high-impedance state, but also clears any active tasks associated with the device.

member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.summary: Creates a that you can use to get the switch channel capabilities and set the usage type for the switch channel.
member.param: The name of the switch channel.
member.returns: A that represents the switch channel.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.CreateSwitchScanTask(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new switch scanning task with the sequence specified in the scan list.
member.param: The name of the task to create. If you specify or , the NI-DAQmx driver assigns a unique name to the new task.
The sequence of connections and disconnections for the task. This sequence is specified using a special syntax.
member.returns: The that this method creates.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks: The NI-DAQmx driver does not determine if the requested settings are possible until the task is verified. does not throw an exception for parameter values that are not compatible with your hardware or other settings in your task. To determine if all of the settings for a are valid, you must verify the task by starting the task, either with or by reading from or writing to the task, or by calling with .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.ConnectSwitchChannels(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes one or more connections between switch channels as specified by the connection list.
member.param: A list of connections to make between switch channels. This list uses a special syntax.
If , this method waits for the switches to settle before returning. If , the method returns immediately after the operation. This settling time is controlled through the property.

remarks.para: You can specify only the two endpoints, or you can specify the explicit path between two endpoints. This method can make connections on multiple devices, but each individual connection must reside on a single device. In the event of an error, connecting stops at the point in the list where the error occurred.

member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.ConnectSwitchChannels(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes a connection between two switch channels.
member.param: The first channel to connect.
The second channel to connect.
If , this method waits for the switches to settle before returning. If , the method returns immediately after the operation. This settling time is controlled through the property.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.DisconnectSwitchChannels(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Terminates one or more connections between switch channels as specified by the disconnection list.
member.param: A list of switch connections to terminate. This list uses a special syntax.
If , this method waits for the switches to settle before returning. If , the method returns immediately after the operation. This settling time is controlled through the property.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.ConnectTerminals(System.String,System.String,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.SignalRoutingModifiers)
member.summary: Creates a route between a source and destination terminal with the specified signal modification.
member.param: The originating terminal of the route.
The receiving terminal of the route.

Specifies if the signal routed from the source terminal to the destination terminal is inverted. If the device is not capable of signal inversion or if a previous route reserved the inversion circuitry in an incompatible configuration, attempting to invert the signal causes an error.
member.remarks: The route can carry a variety of digital signals such as triggers, clocks, and hardware events. These source and destination terminals can be on different devices, as long as a connecting public bus, such as RTSI or the PXI backplane, is available. This method does not modify a task. When the method is called, the route is immediately reserved and committed to hardware. This type of routing is called immediate routing.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.SetDevicePowerUpState(System.String,System.String[],NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DigitalPowerUpState[])
member.summary: Updates the power up states to which to set digital physical channels on a device when the device powers up or when you reset the device.
member.param: The name, as configured in Measurement Automation Explorer (MAX), of the device to which this operation applies.

The digital lines or ports for which to set new power up states. Each value in this array specifies a virtual channel string that is assigned the power up state at the corresponding position in the parameter. You cannot set power up states for dedicated digital input lines. You can specify a string that contains a list or range of digital lines or ports.
The physical channels and power up states to set. Each value in this array applies to the virtual channel name at the corresponding position of the parameter.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks: Power up states are stored in EEPROMs that you can write to only a limited number of times. Therefore, you should use this method as infrequently as possible. This method writes to the EEPROM only if a setting you request is different from the one currently stored on the EEPROM. This method writes power up states in the sequential order of the power up states array. Therefore, any physical channels with multiple entries in that array use the highest array index.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.SetDevicePowerUpState(System.String,System.String[],System.Double[],System.String[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Updates the power up states to which to set analog physical channels on a device when the device powers up or when you reset the device.
member.param: The name, as configured in Measurement Automation Explorer (MAX), of the device to which this operation applies.

The voltage channels for which to set new power up values. Each value in this array specifies a virtual channel string that is assigned the voltage at the corresponding position in the parameter. You can set voltage power up states only for physical channels that support voltage output.

The voltages to set. Each value in this array applies to the virtual channel name at the corresponding position of the parameter. You can set voltage power up states only for physical channels that support voltage output.

The current channels for which to set new power up values. Each value in this array specifies a virtual channel string that is assigned the current at the corresponding position in the parameter. You can set current power up states only for physical channels that support current output.

The currents to set. Each value in this array applies to the virtual channel name at the corresponding position of the parameter. You can set current power up states only for physical channels that support current output.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: Power up states are stored in EEPROMs that you can write to only a limited number of times. Therefore, you should use this method as infrequently as possible. This method writes to the EEPROM only if a setting you request is different from the one currently stored on the EEPROM. This method writes power up states in the sequential order of the power up states array. Therefore, any physical channels with multiple entries in that array use the highest array index.
When you call this method, you can choose to not set either voltages or currents by passing in for the voltage or current parameters, but not both.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.CreateWatchdogTimerTask(System.String,System.String,System.Double,System.String[],NationalInstruments.DAQmx.WatchdogDOExpirationState[])
member.summary: Creates a task to configure and control the watchdog timer of a static DIO device. The timer activates when you start the task.
member.param: The name of the task to create. If you specify or , the NI-DAQmx driver assigns a unique name to the new task.
The name of the device for which to create a watchdog timer task.
The amount of time in seconds until the watchdog timer expires. A value of 1 means the internal timer never expires. Set to 1 if you use an Expiration Trigger to expire the watchdog task.

The physical channel names for which to define watchdog expiration states. Each value in this vector specifies a physical channel string that is assigned the expiration state at the corresponding position in the parameter. You cannot modify the expiration state of dedicated digital input physical channels.
The state to which to set the digital physical channel when the watchdog timer expires.
member.returns: The that this method creates.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks: Use the properties and methods on and to configure and control the watchdog timer task.

member.param: The task instance to save.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks:
You may save a task under a different name by calling .
This method sets the option for the saved task and uses an empty string for the task . You can specify your own options and author value by using the overload.
You cannot view programmatically saved tasks in the DAQ Assistant for versions of NI-DAQ earlier than 7.4. To view a programmatically saved task in an earlier version of NI-DAQ, first use the DAQ Assistant in NI-DAQ 7.4 or later to save the task.
Visit the DAQmx Professional Developer Tools Web site for more information and examples of programmatically saving tasks.

Gets or sets the object that marshals event-handler and callback calls. The representing the object that marshals the event-handler and callback calls. The default value is .

When the value of this property is , event-handler and callback calls are raised in the default manner. This behavior could mean that the calls happen from a thread other than the main thread. Avoid this behavior by setting this property to an object that implements , such as a or .
For more information, refer to Events, Callbacks, and Thread Safety in Measurement Studio .NET Class Libraries.

members.member:
Specifies how events and callback delegates are invoked.
if events and callbacks are invoked through or . Otherwise, events and callbacks are invoked directly. The default value is .
In some cases, callbacks and event handlers are executed in a different thread than the rest of the program. Therefore, you must take special care when accessing objects that have thread affinity, such as UI controls, from these callbacks and event handlers. For more information, refer to Events, Callbacks, and Thread Safety in Measurement Studio .NET Class Libraries.
Reading and Writing with the NI-DAQmx .NET Library Events, Callbacks, and Thread Safety in Measurement Studio .NET Class Libraries.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.SetLogicFamilyPowerUpState(System.String,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.LogicFamily)
member.summary: Sets the digital logic family to use when the device powers up.
member.param: The name, as configured in Measurement Automation Explorer (MAX), of the device to which this operation applies.

The logic family to set the device to when it powers up. A logic family corresponds to voltage thresholds that are compatible with a group of voltage standards. Refer to device documentation for information on the logic high and logic low voltages for these logic families.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: Power-up states are stored in non-volatile memory that you can write to only a limited number of times. Therefore, you should use this function as infrequently as possible. This function writes to the non-volatile memory only if a setting you request is different from the one currently stored on the non-volatile memory.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.AutoConfigureCDaqSynchronizationConnections(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: Detects and configures cDAQ Sync connections between devices.
member.param: The names of the CompactDAQ chassis, C Series modules, or cDAQ Sync ports in comma separated form to search. If no names are specified, all cDAQ Sync ports on connected, non-simulated devices are scanned.
The time in seconds to wait for the device to respond before timing out. If a timeout occurs, no configuration is changed.
member.returns: The configured port-to-port connections.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks: Stop all NI-DAQmx tasks running on the devices prior to calling this method because any running tasks cause auto-configuration to fail. Auto-configure toggles lines on ports during configuration. Upon completion, all previous configurations are deleted.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.GetDisconnectedCDaqSynchronizationPorts(System.String,System.Double,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Verifies configured cDAQ Sync connections between devices.
member.param: The names of the CompactDAQ chassis, C Series modules, or cDAQ Sync ports in comma separated form to search. If no names are specified, all cDAQ Sync ports on connected, non-simulated devices are scanned.
The time in seconds to wait for the device to respond before timing out. If a timeout occurs, no configuration is changed.
Indicates if any port connections are unverified.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.returns: The port-to-port connections that failed verification.
member.remarks: Failures generally indicate a wiring issue or that a device has been powered off or removed. Stop all NI-DAQmx tasks running on the devices prior to running this method because any running tasks cause the verification process to fail.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqSystem.SetAnalogPowerUpStatesWithOutputType(System.String,System.Double[],NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AOPowerUpOutputBehavior[])
member.summary: Sets the states that analog physical channels on a device are set to when the device powers up or when the device is reset.
member.remarks: Power-up states are stored in EEPROMs that you can write to only a limited number of times. Therefore, you should use this method as infrequently as possible. This method writes to the EEPROM only if a setting you request is different from the one currently stored on the EEPROM. This method writes power-up states in sequential order. Therefore, if a physical channel has multiple entries, the last entry is used.
member.param: The physical channels that were modified.
The 1D array listing the power-up states for each corresponding physical channel. If the channel type for the physical channel is high-impedance, this value is 0.
The value set for the physical channel when the device powers up or when the device is reset. You specify this value with .

This method writes to the EEPROM only if a setting you request is different from the one currently stored on the EEPROM. This method writes power-up states in sequential order. Therefore, if a physical channel has multiple entries, the last entry is used.
member.param: The physical channels that were modified.
The 1D array listing the power-up states for each corresponding physical channel. If the channel type for the physical channel is high-impedance, this value is 0.
The value set for the physical channel when the device powers up or when the device is reset. You specify this value with .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.PolynomialScale
member.summary: Encapsulates a custom scale that scales values by using an nth-order polynomial equation.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.PolynomialScale.#ctor(System.String,System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with the specified forward and reverse coefficients.
member.param: The name of the custom scale for later use, such as when you create a virtual channel.

The array of the forward coefficients of the polynomial. Each element of the array corresponds to a term of the equation. For example, if index three of the array is 9, the fourth term of the equation is 9x3.

The array of the reverse coefficients of the polynomial. Each element of the array corresponds to a term of the equation. For example, if index three of the array is 9, the fourth term of the equation is 9y3.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.PolynomialScale.#ctor(System.String,NationalInstruments.DAQmx.PolynomialDirection,System.Double[],System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with the specified forward or reverse coefficients and automatically computes the other set of coefficients with the same order as the provided coefficients, using 1000 points in the specified range.
member.param: The name of the custom scale for later use, such as when you create a virtual channel.
The conversion direction of the specified polynomial. The opposite polynomial is computed by the .

The array of coefficients of a polynomial. Each element of the array corresponds to a term of the equation. For example, if index three of the array is 9, the fourth term of the equation is 9x3. This polynomial is used as either the forward or reverse polynomial depending on the direction specified.
The minimum of the range over which the polynomial specified is valid or of interest.
The maximum of the range over which the polynomial specified is valid or of interest.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

The array of coefficients of a polynomial. Each element of the array corresponds to a term of the equation. For example, if index three of the array is 9, the fourth term of the equation is 9x3. This polynomial is used as either the forward or reverse polynomial depending on the direction specified.
The minimum of the range over which the polynomial specified is valid or of interest.
The maximum of the range over which the polynomial specified is valid or of interest.
The number of points to evaluate for computing the polynomial of the opposite direction.
The order of polynomial to compute for the opposite polynomial to the one provided. Specify 1 to use the same order as the forward polynomial.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TableScale
member.summary: Encapsulates a custom scale that maps an array of prescaled values to an array of corresponding scaled values, with all other values scaled proportionally.

example.para: The following example explains how to update the property that returns an array:
example.code:
Dim preScaledValues As Double() = New Double() {0.11, 0.12, 0.13} Dim scaledValues As Double() = New Double() {1.1, 1.2, 1.3} Dim tablescale As New TableScale("DAQmxTableScale", preScaledValues, scaledValues)
' To update the value at specific index in tablescale.PreScaledValues ' change the source array and assign it back to the property. preScaledValues(0) = 0.1 tablescale.PreScaledValues = preScaledValues

example.para: The following example explains how to update the property that returns an array:
example.code:
Dim preScaledValues As Double() = New Double() {0.11, 0.12, 0.13} Dim scaledValues As Double() = New Double() {1.1, 1.2, 1.3} Dim tablescale As New TableScale("DAQmxTableScale", preScaledValues, scaledValues)
' To update the value at specific index in tablescale.ScaledValues ' change the source array and assign it back to the property. scaledValues(0) = 1.12 tablescale.ScaledValues = scaledValues

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.ExportSignals.CounterOutputEventOutputBehavior
member.summary: Specifies whether the exported Counter Output Event pulses or changes from one state to the other when the counter reaches terminal count.
member.value: Specifies whether the exported Counter Output Event pulses or changes from one state to the other when the counter reaches terminal count.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: Upon reaching terminal count, the counter can issue a pulse. Use to select a high or low pulse.

Upon reaching terminal count, the output terminal of the counter can change state, or toggle. For example, if the terminal is initially at a low state, it changes to high state and stays at the high state until the next terminal count. The terminal then changes to low state. Use to select the initial state of the terminal.
When counting up, a counter reaches terminal count when it reaches the maximum value (2^24 - 1 for a 24-bit counter). When counting down, a counter reaches terminal count when it reaches 0.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogEdgeReferenceTrigger.Hysteresis
member.summary: Specifies a hysteresis level in the units of the measurement. If is , the trigger does not deassert until the source signal passes below minus the hysteresis. If is , the trigger does not deassert until the source signal passes above plus the hysteresis. Hysteresis is always enabled. Set this property to a non-zero value to use hysteresis.
member.value: Specifies a hysteresis level in the units of the measurement. If is , the trigger does not deassert until the source signal passes below minus the hysteresis. member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogEdgeReferenceTrigger.DigitalFilterEnable
member.summary: Specifies whether to apply a digital filter to the digital output of the analog triggering circuitry (the Analog Comparison Event). When enabled, the analog signal must stay above or below the trigger level for the minimum pulse width before being recognized. Use filtering for noisy trigger signals that transition in and out of the hysteresis window rapidly.

member.summary: Resets a switch device and sets its topology.
member.param: The switch topology to use on the device.
member.remarks: This method differs from because it uses the value of rather than the topology specified in Measurement Automation Explorer (MAX). However, this method maintains the channel usage defaults that you configure in MAX.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Switch.WaitForSettling
member.summary: Waits for the settling time on the device to expire.
member.remarks: The settling time is reset and begins counting down upon a switch operation. Therefore, this method might return immediately if no operation happened recently.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.Switch.SettlingTime
member.summary: Specifies in seconds the amount of time to wait for the switch to settle (or debounce). NI-DAQmx adds this time to the settling time of the motherboard. member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TaskAction
member.summary: Specifies how to alter the state of the task.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TaskAction.Commit
member.summary: Programs the hardware with all parameters of the task.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TaskAction.Start
member.summary: Transitions the task to the running state, which begins device input or output.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TaskAction.Unreserve
member.summary: Releases all previously reserved resources.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TaskAction.Reserve
member.summary: Marks the hardware resources that are needed for the task as in use. No other tasks can reserve these same resources.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TaskAction.Verify
member.summary: Verifies that all task parameters are valid for the hardware.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TaskAction.Stop
member.summary: Transitions the task from the running state to the committed state, which ends device input or output.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.TaskAction.Abort
member.summary: Aborts execution of the task. Aborting a task immediately terminates the currently active operation, such as a read or a write. Aborting a task puts the task into an unstable but recoverable state. To recover the task, use to restart the task or use to reset the task without starting it.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.ChannelLineGrouping
member.summary: Specifies how to group digital lines into one or more virtual channels.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.ChannelLineGrouping.OneChannelForAllLines
member.summary: All digital lines are combined into a single virtual channel.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.ChannelLineGrouping.OneChannelForEachLine
member.summary: A separate virtual channel is created for each digital line.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.SwitchPathStatus.SourceChannelConflict

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.SwitchPathStatus.PathUnsupported

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.SwitchPathStatus.PathAlreadyExists

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqStream.LoggingFilePath
member.summary: Specifies the path to the TDMS file to which you want to log data. If the file path is changed while the task is running, this takes effect on the next sample interval (if Logging.SampsPerFile has been set) or when DAQmx Start New File is called. New file paths can be specified by ending with "\" or "/". Files created after specifying a new file path retain the same name and numbering sequence.
member.value: Specifies the path to the TDMS file to which you want to log data. If the file path is changed while the task is running, this takes effect on the next sample interval (if Logging.SampsPerFile has been set) or when DAQmx Start New File is called. New file paths can be specified by ending with "\" or "/". Files created after specifying a new file path retain the same name and numbering sequence.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqStream.LoggingMode
member.summary: Specifies whether to enable logging and whether to allow reading data while logging. Log mode allows for the best performance. However, you cannot read data while logging if you specify this mode. If you want to read data while logging, specify Log and Read mode.
member.value: Specifies whether to enable logging and whether to allow reading data while logging. Log mode allows for the best performance. However, you cannot read data while logging if you specify this mode. If you want to read data while logging, specify Log and Read mode.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqStream.TdmsLoggingGroupName
member.summary: Specifies the name of the group to create within the TDMS file for data from this task. If you append data to an existing file and the specified group already exists, NI-DAQmx appends a number symbol and a number to the group name, incrementing that number until finding a group name that does not exist. For example, if you specify a group name of Voltage Task, and that group already exists, NI-DAQmx assigns the group name Voltage Task #1, then Voltage Task #2.
member.value: Specifies the name of the group to create within the TDMS file for data from this task. If you append data to an existing file and the specified group already exists, NI-DAQmx appends a number symbol and a number to the group name, incrementing that number until finding a group name that does not exist. For example, if you specify a group name of Voltage Task, and that group already exists, NI-DAQmx assigns the group name Voltage Task #1, then Voltage Task #2.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

remarks.para: For digital input tasks, NI-DAQmx creates a group for each virtual channel in the task. For each created group, NI-DAQmx appends a hyphen and the virtual channel name to the group name.
If you query this property, NI-DAQmx returns the original value specified without any suffixes appended by NI-DAQmx for digital input tasks or for existing groups.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqStream.LoggingPause
member.summary: Specifies whether logging is paused while a task is executing. If is set to Log and Read mode, this value is taken into consideration on the next call to DAQmx Read, where data is written to disk. If is set to Log Only mode, this value is taken into consideration the next time that data is written to disk. A new TDMS group is written when logging is resumed from a paused state.
member.value: Specifies whether logging is paused while a task is executing. If is set to Log and Read mode, this value is taken into consideration on the next call to DAQmx Read, where data is written to disk. If is set to Log Only mode, this value is taken into consideration the next time that data is written to disk. A new TDMS group is written when logging is resumed from a paused state.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqStream.LoggingSamplesPerFile
member.summary: Specifies how many samples to write to each file. When the file reaches the number of samples specified, a new file is created with the naming convention of <filename>_####.tdms, where #### starts at 0001 and increments automatically with each new file. For example, if the file specified is C:\data.tdms, the next file name used is C:\data_0001.tdms. To disable file spanning behavior, set this attribute to 0. If is changed while this attribute is set, the new file path takes effect on the next file created.
member.value: Specifies how many samples to write to each file. When the file reaches the number of samples specified, a new file is created with the naming convention of <filename>_####.tdms, where #### starts at 0001 and increments automatically with each new file. For example, if the file specified is C:\data.tdms, the next file name used is C:\data_0001.tdms. To disable file spanning behavior, set this attribute to 0. If is changed while this attribute is set, the new file path takes effect on the next file created.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqStream.LoggingFileWriteSize

member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqStream.LoggingFilePreallocationSize
member.summary: Specifies a size in samples to be used to pre-allocate space on disk. Pre-allocation can improve file I/O performance, especially in situations where multiple files are being written to disk. For finite tasks, the default behavior is to pre-allocate the file based on the number of samples you configure the task to acquire.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogMultiChannelWriter
member.summary: Contains methods for writing samples to one or more analog output channels in a task.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogMultiChannelWriter.#ctor(NationalInstruments.DAQmx.DaqStream)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class to write to the specified .
member.param: The to write to.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks:
Each object contains a property that serves as the connection point for writers to provide samples to be generated by that task.
NI-DAQmx read and write methods time out after the amount of time specified by the property on the task you are reading from or writing to.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogMultiChannelWriter.WriteSingleSample(System.Boolean,System.Double[])
member.summary: Writes a single floating-point sample to one or more objects in a task.
member.param: If set to this method automatically calls if you do not explicitly call it. You cannot set this parameter to if you have installed events on the task.

A 1D array of samples to write to the task. Each element of the array corresponds to a channel in the task. The order of the channels in the array corresponds to the order in which you add the channels to the task.
member.remarks:
NI-DAQmx scales the generated data to the units of the measurement, including any custom scaling you apply to the channel. You specify these units with the create channel methods or the DAQ Assistant.
NI-DAQmx read and write methods time out after the amount of time specified by the property on the task you are reading from or writing to.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
has a non-zero lower bound.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogMultiChannelWriter.WriteMultiSample(System.Boolean,System.Double[0:,0:])
member.summary: Writes one or more floating-point samples to one or more objects in a task.
member.param: If set to this method automatically calls if you do not explicitly call it. You cannot set this parameter to if you have installed events on the task.

A 2D array of samples to write to the task. Each element in the first dimension of the array corresponds to a channel in the task. Each element in the second dimension of the array corresponds to a sample to write to each channel. The order of the channels in the array corresponds to the order in which you add the channels to the task.
member.remarks:
NI-DAQmx scales the generated data to the units of the measurement, including any custom scaling you apply to the channel. You specify these units with the create channel methods or the DAQ Assistant.
If the task uses on-demand timing, this method returns only after the device generates all samples. If the task uses any timing type other than on-demand, this method returns immediately and does not wait for the device to generate all samples. Your application must call the method to block until the device has generated all samples.
NI-DAQmx read and write methods time out after the amount of time specified by the property on the task you are reading from or writing to.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
has a non-zero lower bound.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogMultiChannelWriter.BeginWriteSingleSample(System.Boolean,System.Double[],System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous write of a single floating-point sample to one or more objects in a task.
member.param: If set to this method automatically calls if you do not explicitly call it. You cannot set this parameter to if you have installed events on the task.

A 1D array of samples to write to the task. Each element of the array corresponds to a channel in the task. The order of the channels in the array corresponds to the order in which you add the channels to the task.
An optional asynchronous callback that is called when the write is complete. Specify if you do not want a callback when the write is complete.

A user-provided object that distinguishes this asynchronous write request from other requests. Use this parameter to provide information to the callback. Specify if you do not need to pass any additional information to the callback.
member.returns: An that represents the asynchronous call.

remarks.para: Pass the returned to to get any exceptions that occurred during the asynchronous write or to wait for the write to complete.

NI-DAQmx scales the generated data to the units of the measurement, including any custom scaling you apply to the channel. You specify these units with the create channel methods or the DAQ Assistant.
NI-DAQmx read and write methods time out after the amount of time specified by the property on the task you are reading from or writing to.
remarks.note: Refer to Asynchronously Reading and Writing with the NI-DAQmx .NET Class Library for additional information.

member.seealso: Asynchronously Reading and Writing with the NI-DAQmx .NET Class Library

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogMultiChannelWriter.EndWrite(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Handles the end of an asynchronous write initiated with or .
member.param: An that represents an asynchronous call started by calling or .

remarks.para: If you call before the asynchronous write represented by the provided is complete, waits for the write to complete before returning. For a write to a buffered task, the write is considered complete when all of the written samples have been transferred to the task buffer. Use or on the object to determine if a task has generated all of the data it was configured to generate.
NI-DAQmx scales the returned data to the units of the measurement, including any custom scaling you apply to the channel. You specify these units with the create channel methods or the DAQ Assistant.
NI-DAQmx read and write methods time out after the amount of time specified by the property on the task you are reading from or writing to.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogMultiChannelWriter.SynchronizingObject
member.summary: Gets or sets the object that marshals event-handler and callback calls.
member.value: The representing the object that marshals the event-handler and callback calls. The default value is .
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
member.remarks:
When the value of this property is , event-handler and callback calls are raised in the default manner. This behavior could mean that the calls happen from a thread other than the main thread. Avoid this behavior by setting this property to an object that implements , such as a or .
For more information, refer to Events, Callbacks, and Thread Safety in Measurement Studio .NET Class Libraries and Asynchronously Reading and Writing with the NI-DAQmx .NET Class Library.
member.seealso: Events, Callbacks, and Thread Safety in Measurement Studio .NET Class Libraries

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogMultiChannelWriter.WriteWaveform``1(System.Boolean,NationalInstruments.AnalogWaveform{``0}[])
member.summary: Writes one or more analog waveform samples to one or more objects in a task.
member.param: If you set autoStart to , WriteWaveform automatically calls if you do not explicitly call . You cannot set this parameter to if you have installed events on the task.

A 1D array of objects to write to the task. Each element in the array corresponds to a channel in the task. The order of the channels in the array corresponds to the order in which you add the channels to the task. The order of the lines in the analog waveform corresponds to the order in which you add the lines to the channel.
member.remarks:
If the task uses on-demand timing, the WriteWaveform method returns only after the device generates all samples. If the task uses any timing type other than on-demand, WriteWaveform returns immediately and does not wait for the device to generate all samples. Your application must call the method to wait until the device has generated all samples.
Analog waveform writes are not affected by the or properties on . To configure timing for analog waveform writes, use the method.
NI-DAQmx read and write methods time out after the amount of time specified by the property on the task you are reading from or writing to.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
has a non-zero lower bound.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogSingleChannelWriter.WriteSingleSample(System.Boolean,System.Double)
member.summary: Writes a floating-point sample to a single in a task.
member.param: If set to this method automatically calls if you do not explicitly call it. You cannot set this parameter to if you have installed events on the task.
A sample to write to the task.
member.remarks:
NI-DAQmx scales the generated data to the units of the measurement, including any custom scaling you apply to the channel. You specify these units with the create channel methods or the DAQ Assistant.
NI-DAQmx read and write methods time out after the amount of time specified by the property on the task you are reading from or writing to.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogSingleChannelWriter.WriteMultiSample(System.Boolean,System.Double[])
member.summary: Writes one or more floating-point samples to a single in a task.
member.param: If set to this method automatically calls if you do not explicitly call it. You cannot set this parameter to if you have installed events on the task.

A 1D array of samples to write to the task. Each element of the array corresponds to a sample to write to the channel. The order of the channels in the array corresponds to the order in which you add the channels to the task.
member.remarks:
NI-DAQmx scales the generated data to the units of the measurement, including any custom scaling you apply to the channel. You specify these units with the create channel methods or the DAQ Assistant.
If the task uses on-demand timing, this method returns only after the device generates all samples. If the task uses any timing type other than on-demand, this method returns immediately and does not wait for the device to generate all samples. Your application must call the method to block until the device has generated all samples.
NI-DAQmx read and write methods time out after the amount of time specified by the property on the task you are reading from or writing to.
member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
has a non-zero lower bound.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogSingleChannelWriter.EndWrite(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Handles the end of an asynchronous write initiated with or .
member.param: An that represents an asynchronous call started by calling or .

remarks.para: If you call before the asynchronous write represented by the provided is complete, waits for the write to complete before returning. For a write to a buffered task, the write is considered complete when all of the written samples have been transferred to the task buffer. Use or on the object to determine if a task has generated all of the data it was configured to generate.
NI-DAQmx scales the returned data to the units of the measurement, including any custom scaling you apply to the channel. You specify these units with the create channel methods or the DAQ Assistant.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.DAQmx.AnalogMultiChannelReader.ReadSingleSample
member.summary: Reads a single floating-point sample from one or more objects in a task.
member.returns: A 1D array of floating-point samples from the task. Each element in the array corresponds to a channel in the task. The order of the channels in the array corresponds to the order in which you add the channels to the task or to the order of the channels you specify in .

member.exception: The NI-DAQmx driver returned an error.
